comments:
I'm running RH9, and whenever I run a JUnit test with SWT on top of GTK, I get
the following error: 
(<unknown>:2895): Gtk-CRITICAL **: file gtkwidget.c: line 4814
(gtk_widget_set_size_request): assertion `height >= -1' failed

This comes up in today's (6/10/03) head version of SWT, as well as 3008, 3007,
and every other one that I've tested back through 2134. 

Unfortunately, I can't seem to come up with a test case because I can't seem to
get this error apart from using JUnit, and I don't have the source for that.
FH to investigate.
I just ran the SWT AllGraphicsTest on eclipse #200305280800 and I had no 
warnings at all.

In your case, you got warninigs regardless of the test case you are running ?
The JUnit view is a fast-view ? are you running from the Java perspective ?
What we have is a suite of JUnit tests that we run using one test that calls 
all the rest of them. When I run the individual tests, no problem is reported; 
everything works like it should. But when I run the test that calls all the 
other ones, this error comes out, and it's only in GTK. 
I usually do run from the Java perspective in WSDD, but I created a bash script 
to run directly from the terminal and the same error is reported. It is 
reported several times in the 3007 and 3008 builds, and only once during the 
latest one (as of 6/10). 
To complicate matters, my linux box was fried on Friday during a thunderstorm, 
so I can't even play with it right now to try and give you more specific 
information. When I get up and running again on linux, I'll try and create a 
test case that just launches JUnit to see if we can narrow the problem down to 
that.
Zack, could I have access to your testcases ? Is it available somewhere ?
Alright, Linux is back up and running and I have for you a very simple JUnit 
test. The code below, which simply creates an empty suite and then calls the 
TestRunner, produces the following error:

(<unknown>:2278): Gtk-CRITICAL **: file gtkwidget.c: line 4814 
(gtk_widget_set_size_request): assertion 'height >= -1' failed

This error is thrown using SWT 3009, and every previous version through 2134. 
It does not stop execution, but does seem to trip up the flow of things. 
Similar errors are thrown throughout the execution of our tests, but only if 
they are run as part of a test suite, rather than individually. 

import junit.awtui.TestRunner;
import junit.framework.Test;
import junit.framework.TestSuite;

public class Run {

	public static Test suite() {
		return suiteTests(true);
	}

	public static Test suiteTests(boolean visual) {

		TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("JUnit Tests");

		return suite;
	}

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		if (args.length == 0) {
			args = new String[] { Run.class.getName()};
		}

		TestRunner.main(args);
	}

}

In order to see the problem with the testcase Zack provided, you will need our 
AWT classes.  Zack is sending you a note offline as to where you can obtain 
these.  Let one of us know if you have any trouble setting up, running, or 
debugging with our AWT code.  You will need to use J9 as your JRE.  Both 
Christophe and Silenio have a lot of experience running our AWT if you want a 
local resource for setting this up.
Zack, could you try the following:

In Decice, change the line:
public static boolean DEBUG;
by:
public static boolean DEBUG = true;

Run your test case again, this time you should get a SWT stacktrace before the 
gtk warning, could you copy it and paste in here or send it to me by mail ?
Thanks


If you don't want to hack SWT code, alternatively you can create a Display as 
follow:
DeviceData data = new DeviceData ();
data.debug = true;
Display display = new Display (data);

And then you do the same test.
Here's the stack trace. Note that the error message is now different.

Here is a test case to recreate the problem, is your code doing something like 
that ?

import org.eclipse.swt.SWT;
import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.*;
import org.eclipse.swt.graphics.*;

public class PR38712 {
	public static void main(String[] args) {
		DeviceData data = new DeviceData ();
		data.debug = true;
		Display display = new Display(data);
		Shell shell = new Shell(display);
		shell.setSize (20, 20); //according to the theme you might need to resize it
smaller to see the warning
		Menu menuBar = new Menu(shell, SWT.BAR);
		shell.setMenuBar(menuBar);
//		shell.open();
//		while (!shell.isDisposed())
//			if (!display.readAndDispatch())
//				display.sleep();
//		display.dispose();
	}
}
Fixed in HEAD > 20030724
